S7.SS2.348.caption:
Table 1: The reported results are in the form of mean accuracy ±plus-or-minus\pm standard deviation and are obtained over 3 repetitions in different random seeds.
Results are averaged over the last 100100100 rounds.
In each simulation, clients perform mini-batch stochastic gradient descent in 555 steps on a convolutional neural network (CNN) locally per round.
The total global rounds for SVHN, CIFAR-10, CINIC-10 are 4000, 10000, 10000, respectively.
Furthermore, we use customized CNNs for different datasets, respectively.
Algorithms are categorized into two groups:
(1) ones not aided by memory or known statistics;
(2) ones with memory (including MIFA and FedAvg with known pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s).
Moreover, we highlight the best and the second best in yellow and in cyan, respectively, among algorithms not aided by memory or known statistics.
The other hyperparameters are specified in Appendix B,
and some of them are tuned using grid search.

Detailed hardware and software specifications
can be found in Appendix B.Dataset and data heterogeneity.
The image classification task is commonly adopted in evaluating the empirical performance of a federated learning system [18, 23, 9, 35].
Following existing literature [18, 23, 9, 35], we base our simulations on SVHN [25], CIFAR-10 [17] and CINIC-10 [7].
All of them include 101010 classes of images of different categories.
For data heterogeneity, we partition all datasets and assign data samples to clients according to a Dirichlet distribution parameterized by α𝛼\alpha [11].
In particular, α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 in Table. 7.2.
A smaller α𝛼\alpha entails a more non-i.i.d. local data distribution and vice versa.
Each client holds the same data volume; the exact data volume may be dataset-dependent.Federated learning system.
We consider m=100𝑚100m=100 clients,
wherein clients continue to compute locally albeit the failures of unreliable communication uplinks.
However, only clients with active links are allowed to submit their local updates. We use three customized convolutional neural networks
for three datasets, respectively.

In addition to a similar unreliable time-invariant communication setup as in [38] for fair competition,
we study a more challenging scenario where pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s change over time.
Specifically, we evaluate FedPBC and a set of baseline algorithms on the following schemes:Bernoulli.
Client i𝑖i submits its local updates to the parameter server when the uplink becomes active with probability pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}.
The first two columns of Table 7.2 demonstrate the results when the probabilities are time-invariant pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’s and time-varying pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s, respectively.
When pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t} is time-invariant, we have pit=pisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡subscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}^{t}=p_{i} for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0,
where pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is the time-invariant base probability in (9).
In the latter,
pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t} is defined as in (9)
and changes over time.Markovian.
The uplink connection probabilities pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s
might be affected by external factors,
leading to an unexpected shutdown after it is on
or,
conversely,
resuming fully operational after it is off.
Specifically,
the uplink availability is dictated by
a Markov chain of two states “ON” and “OFF”,
whose initial state is determined by a Bernoulli sampling.
Depending on whether
the transition probabilities
change over time,
we have a homogeneous Markov chain
(the third row of Table 7.2)
or
a non-homogeneous Markov chain
(the fourth row).
The detailed illustration of the transition probabilities is deferred to Appendix B.Cyclic.
The communication uplink between the parameter server and the clients can have a cyclic pattern,
where the client has a fixed working schedule and joins the training diurnally or nocturnally [6, 3].
A random offset at the beginning of the whole process is used to simulate and reflect the initial shift due to each client’s device heterogeneity [38].
Please refer to Fig. 4(a) for details.
However,
it is also possible that each client’s schedule to start training varies each day,
which motivates us to devise the second scheme with periodic reset in Fig. 4(b).
The key difference is that the random offset will be reset at the beginning of each cycle, not only at the first cycle.
Notice that the interval for a link to become active is now stochastic, rather than fixed.Fig. 6 shows an example of uplink statuses under the unreliable communication schemes we evaluate.
It is observed that uplinks become less frequently active when probabilities change from time-invariant (Fig. 5(a)) to time-varying (Fig. 5(b)).
In addition,
the uplinks become even more sparsely active when the schemes move to Markovian in Fig. 5(c) and 5(d).
On the other hand,
the cyclic unreliable scheme exhibits a different pattern:
the uplinks in Fig. 4(a) become active and inactive in alternation
after an initial random offset.
Notice that
the uplink’s offline duration
is always fixed.
In contrast,
the duration remains random in Fig. 4(b) due to a reset at the beginning of each cycle.Baseline algorithms.

F3AST [29],
and MIFA [9].
Under FedAvg all,
the parameter server averages all clients’ local updates,
wherein the contributions of clients with inactive communication links are deemed zeros.
FedAvg known pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s requires the time-varying pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s to be a known prior.

2700It turns out that MIFA,
aided by 100100100 units of old local gradients,
does not always achieve the best performance.
We conjecture it to the old gradients induced by a lower participation rate.
Fig. 3(b) shows that most probabilities fall below 0.10.10.1 under our construction of pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’ s, which means that an uplink could be inactive for a long time before waking up again.
Although clients in FedPBC start in each global round from its own staled local model,
the expected staleness is upper bounded (see Proposition 2).
It is not surprising that F3AST acts inferior to FedPBC.
At a high level,
F3AST caps 𝒜tsuperscript𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}^{t} to a few representative clients for local optimization, excluding the rest of the clients within 𝒜tsuperscript𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}^{t}.
FedPBC surpasses FedAU in all scenarios in terms of train accuracy.
Although FedAU develops an online average method to estimate the underlying connection probabilities, it cannot tolerate complex dynamics.
This can be observed in the performance degradation when switching from cyclic without periodic restart to cyclic with periodic restart.
In the former, the uplinks are activated alternately with a fixed interval after the initial random offset, whereas in the latter, they are switched on stochastically, making it much more challenging.
In the case of time-invariant pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’s, the outperformance of our
FedPBC may stem from its utilization of true gradient trajectories to account for inactivities. This approach may result in better compensation than the online estimate used in FedAU.

Choosing η≤1−ρ6​L​s𝜂1𝜌6𝐿𝑠\eta\leq\frac{1-\sqrt{\rho}}{6Ls} and by Proposition 3, we have∎In this paper,
we study federated learning
in the presence of
stochastic uplink communications
that are allowed to be simultaneously
time-varying and unknown to all parties
in the distributed learning system.
We show that,
by using a simple quadratic counterexample in Proposition 1,
the seminal work FedAvg
is inherently biased from the global optimum
under non-i.i.d. local data.
We propose FedPBC,
which leverages implicit gossiping by postponing the broadcast till the end of each global round,
is provable to reach a stationary point of the global non-convex objective,
and converges at the optimal rate in the presence of smooth non-convex and stochastic objective gradients.
Extensive experiments have been provided over diversified unreliable patterns to corroborate our analysis.
Numerous directions are open for future research.
First, our work can be extended by studying unreliable bidirectional communication links.
We expect to incorporate different local optimization methods,
other than stochastic gradient descent,
and establish provable guarantees.

The simulations are performed on a private cluster with 64 CPUs, 500 GB RAM and 8 NVIDIA A5000 GPU cards.

As recommended by [38],
we choose K=50𝐾50K=50 for FedAU without further specification.

All the datasets we evaluate contain 10 classes of images.
Some data enhancement tricks that are standard in training image classifiers are applied during training.
Specifically,
we apply random cropping to all datasets.
Furthermore, random horizontal flipping is applied to CIFAR-10 and CINIC-10.
SVHN [25]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different number digits.
In total,
there are 73257 train images and 26032 test images.
CIFAR-10 [17]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different objects.
In total,
there are 50000 train images and 10000 test images.
CINIC-10[7]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different objects.
In total,
there are 90000 train images and 90000 test images.Constructions of Markov transition probabilities.

In this part,
we conduct ablation experiments to study the impact of different parameters on the performance of FedPBC and the other baseline algorithms.
Specifically, we evaluate all algorithms on the CIFAR-10 dataset under the Bernoulli unreliable communication scheme with time-varying pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s.
In any set of experiments, only one system design parameter is changed,
while the others remain the same as in Table 7.2.
We report the mean test accuracy over the last 100 rounds in bar plots in Fig. 9.
Algorithms are divided into two groups:
those with additional memory or known historical statistics (bars with backslashes) and those without.
It is observed that FedPBC outperforms the baseline algorithms not aided by memory in almost all cases (except when α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0 by FedAU in Fig. 8(a) and σ0=1.0subscript𝜎01.0\sigma_{0}=1.0 by FedAU in Fig. 8(d).)
The reason why FedPBC trails behind FedAU in the above two cases is worth further investigation.
Compared to memory-aided algorithms,
although MIFA occasionally dwarfs FedPBC,
the benefit margin is lower than 2% in test accuracy.Impact of data heterogeneity α𝛼\alpha.
In the presence of more homogenous local data,
i.e.,
a larger α𝛼\alpha,
the bias phenomenon gradually disappears as the local objectives become interchangeable,
which is confirmed by Fig. 8(a) from the on-par performance of almost all algorithms when α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0.Impact of fluctuation γ𝛾\gamma.
The magnitude of the sine function is defined as γ𝛾\gamma and thus governs the fluctuations of pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s.
It can be seen that the test accuracies of all algorithms decrease as γ𝛾\gamma increases.
This is intuitive, as enlarged fluctuations impose new challenges.
It is observed that FedPBC outperforms all algorithms that are not aided by memory.Impact of a cutting-off lower bound δ𝛿\delta.

Notice that FedPBC remains the best among the algorithms not aided by memory in terms of test accuracy.
At one challenging extreme (when δ=0.001𝛿0.001\delta=0.001),
all algorithms experience significant drops in accuracy,
in particular MIFA.
This confirms our conjecture that the old gradient might lead to staled updates and affect performance.Impact of contribution heterogeneity σ0subscript𝜎0\sigma_{0}.

2700It turns out that MIFA,
aided by 100100100 units of old local gradients,
does not always achieve the best performance.
We conjecture it to the old gradients induced by a lower participation rate.
Fig. 3(b) shows that most probabilities fall below 0.10.10.1 under our construction of pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’ s, which means that an uplink could be inactive for a long time before waking up again.
Although clients in FedPBC start in each global round from its own staled local model,
the expected staleness is upper bounded (see Proposition 2).
It is not surprising that F3AST acts inferior to FedPBC.
At a high level,
F3AST caps 𝒜tsuperscript𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}^{t} to a few representative clients for local optimization, excluding the rest of the clients within 𝒜tsuperscript𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}^{t}.
FedPBC surpasses FedAU in all scenarios in terms of train accuracy.
Although FedAU develops an online average method to estimate the underlying connection probabilities, it cannot tolerate complex dynamics.
This can be observed in the performance degradation when switching from cyclic without periodic restart to cyclic with periodic restart.
In the former, the uplinks are activated alternately with a fixed interval after the initial random offset, whereas in the latter, they are switched on stochastically, making it much more challenging.
In the case of time-invariant pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’s, the outperformance of our
FedPBC may stem from its utilization of true gradient trajectories to account for inactivities. This approach may result in better compensation than the online estimate used in FedAU.
Though FedAvg with known probability uses the ground truth 1/pit1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡1/p_{i}^{t} to mimic the empirical length of the uplink active interval,
as pointed out in [38],
the empirical length can unfortunately deviate far from the ground truth 1/pit1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡1/p_{i}^{t}.To complement the numerical results in the main section,
we also study the impact of different system-design parameters,
including α,γ,δ,σ0𝛼𝛾𝛿subscript𝜎0\alpha,~{}\gamma,~{}\delta,~{}\sigma_{0},
on learning performance.

we empirically conclude that the staleness in FedPBC is mild

Choosing η≤1−ρ6​L​s𝜂1𝜌6𝐿𝑠\eta\leq\frac{1-\sqrt{\rho}}{6Ls} and by Proposition 3, we have∎In this paper,
we study federated learning
in the presence of
stochastic uplink communications
that are allowed to be simultaneously
time-varying and unknown to all parties
in the distributed learning system.
We show that,
by using a simple quadratic counterexample in Proposition 1,
the seminal work FedAvg
is inherently biased from the global optimum
under non-i.i.d. local data.
We propose FedPBC,
which leverages implicit gossiping by postponing the broadcast till the end of each global round,
is provable to reach a stationary point of the global non-convex objective,
and converges at the optimal rate in the presence of smooth non-convex and stochastic objective gradients.
Extensive experiments have been provided over diversified unreliable patterns to corroborate our analysis.
Numerous directions are open for future research.
First, our work can be extended by studying unreliable bidirectional communication links.
We expect to incorporate different local optimization methods,
other than stochastic gradient descent,
and establish provable guarantees.
Finally,
it is also interesting to explore achieving the desired linear speedup property.AppendixAt each client i∈𝒜t,𝑖superscript𝒜𝑡i\in{\mathcal{A}}^{t}, for each local step k=0,⋯,s−1𝑘0⋯𝑠1k=0,\cdots,s-1, we haveIt follows thatTaking expectation with respect to 𝒜tsuperscript𝒜𝑡{\mathcal{A}}^{t}, we getFollowing from the fact that pit=pisuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡subscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}^{t}=p_{i} for all t𝑡t at all clients,

The simulations are performed on a private cluster with 64 CPUs, 500 GB RAM and 8 NVIDIA A5000 GPU cards.
We code the experiments based on PyTorch 1.13.1 [26] and Python 3.7.16.Neural Network and Hyper-parameter Specifications.

we specify the missing essential hyperparameters for specific algorithm implementations.
As recommended by [38],
we choose K=50𝐾50K=50 for FedAU without further specification.
Note that K𝐾K is an algorithmic hyperparameter in FedAU.
Adopting the setup in [29],
we set the communication constraint to be 101010 clients for F3AST.Datasets.
All the datasets we evaluate contain 10 classes of images.
Some data enhancement tricks that are standard in training image classifiers are applied during training.
Specifically,
we apply random cropping to all datasets.
Furthermore, random horizontal flipping is applied to CIFAR-10 and CINIC-10.
SVHN [25]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different number digits.
In total,
there are 73257 train images and 26032 test images.
CIFAR-10 [17]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different objects.
In total,
there are 50000 train images and 10000 test images.
CINIC-10[7]
dataset contains 32×\times32 colored images of 10 different objects.
In total,
there are 90000 train images and 90000 test images.Constructions of Markov transition probabilities.

In this part,
we conduct ablation experiments to study the impact of different parameters on the performance of FedPBC and the other baseline algorithms.
Specifically, we evaluate all algorithms on the CIFAR-10 dataset under the Bernoulli unreliable communication scheme with time-varying pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s.
In any set of experiments, only one system design parameter is changed,
while the others remain the same as in Table 7.2.
We report the mean test accuracy over the last 100 rounds in bar plots in Fig. 9.
Algorithms are divided into two groups:
those with additional memory or known historical statistics (bars with backslashes) and those without.
It is observed that FedPBC outperforms the baseline algorithms not aided by memory in almost all cases (except when α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0 by FedAU in Fig. 8(a) and σ0=1.0subscript𝜎01.0\sigma_{0}=1.0 by FedAU in Fig. 8(d).)
The reason why FedPBC trails behind FedAU in the above two cases is worth further investigation.
Compared to memory-aided algorithms,
although MIFA occasionally dwarfs FedPBC,
the benefit margin is lower than 2% in test accuracy.Impact of data heterogeneity α𝛼\alpha.
In the presence of more homogenous local data,
i.e.,
a larger α𝛼\alpha,
the bias phenomenon gradually disappears as the local objectives become interchangeable,
which is confirmed by Fig. 8(a) from the on-par performance of almost all algorithms when α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0.Impact of fluctuation γ𝛾\gamma.
The magnitude of the sine function is defined as γ𝛾\gamma and thus governs the fluctuations of pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s.
It can be seen that the test accuracies of all algorithms decrease as γ𝛾\gamma increases.
This is intuitive, as enlarged fluctuations impose new challenges.
It is observed that FedPBC outperforms all algorithms that are not aided by memory.Impact of a cutting-off lower bound δ𝛿\delta.
Recall that pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}’s might be too small and close to 00 due to the unbalanced class contributions in 𝒓𝒓\bm{r}.
We show in Lemma 3 that a smaller lower bound c𝑐c of pitsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡p_{i}^{t}’s slows down convergence and incurs a looser bound in Theorem 1.
Notice that FedPBC remains the best among the algorithms not aided by memory in terms of test accuracy.
At one challenging extreme (when δ=0.001𝛿0.001\delta=0.001),
all algorithms experience significant drops in accuracy,
